am neither forced, compelled, nor deceived, but with a willing spirit. i free, release, and clear bahiyya bt. yaish wife of mevorakh b. ephraim from the deed i had against her in muslim courts and i ai_translation: Mevorakḥ bar Movo... gold coins. To the non-Jewish bath attendant, the gold coins. The non-Jew to Amram. Amram saw a woman under Jewish law, for he had pity on them, that she was a married woman, all... And discussions passed between them in the court. And he said to them that it is proper for you to make a compromise between yourselves in Jewish law. Do not go to non-Jewish courts, for the document in Amram's possession is valid under non-Jewish law. The court and the elders had compassion for the woman, and the elders intervened between them and negotiated the matter. After they saw that the remaining amount in the document was forty-two gold coins that needed to be given to Amram today, Amram decided to show them kindness and take from them thirty gold coins. The rest he hoped the non-Jew would give to him as a gift. Amram agreed to this with a formal acquisition. The elders decreed upon the woman's husband, Mevorakḥ, and compelled him to give half of the thirty gold coins so that his wife would not be dragged into non-Jewish courts. He was unwilling to give half, and they warned him with soft and good words until he paid Amram eleven good, weighed gold coins out of the thirty. And the document is on Jacob ben Ye'ish the Kohen, brother of Bahiya, wife of Mevorakḥ bar Ephraim. They all agreed to this compromise. When Mevorakḥ, Bahiya's husband, paid the eleven gold coins to Amram, he requested to write for his wife a strong release document from Amram and to take the non-Jewish document in his possession. As this request was true, the court ordered and wrote a release document for Bahiya, which is as follows: Amram bar Yefet came to the court and the elders signing their testimony on this document and said, Be witnesses for me and acquire from me in every language of merit, and write and sign your testimony upon me. I am not under duress, not forced, not persuaded, but with a willing soul, I have cleared and released and absolved Bahiya bat Ye'ish from what I had against her in non-Jewish law, and I have given it to her husband Mevorakḥ. I have no claim remaining against her in the world, neither in Jewish law nor in non-Jewish law. I have nullified all notices I have given or may give from today and forever, and I have forgiven her a complete forgiveness, an eternal forgiveness. Also, I have no remaining ban, oath, or curse against her, neither by inducement nor by Torah. We acquired from Amram bar Yefet a complete and serious acquisition with a proper vessel, in order to acquire with it, and this document should be strong, established, and accepted like the substance and strength of all release documents that the rabbis instituted and are practiced in the world. Written on Thursday, the 20th of the month of Av, in Fustat, Egypt, which is on the Nile River, in the year 1368 of the Seleucid era. We gave this document to Bahiya for her merit. [Signatures of witnesses and court officials follow] This document was validated before us in court... [Additional signatures and validations]

ai_translation: O my master, my elder, and my superior, may God perpetuate your well-being and increase your honor. I acknowledge everything...  O my master, may God prolong your life and protect you from harm. I suffered from an illness... When I recovered, mercy helped me leave, and I left everything...  O my master, of all I had, only two dinars remained. I used them all and nothing was left. I found myself in need... Then, after their kind treatment of me, I ask the Honored One to increase their kindness and show them the good path to follow.  Then, O my master, I arrived in Alexandria, and the people of Alexandria treated me with great kindness. May God increase their kindness and mercy and show them the good path.  The people of Alexandria wrote to our rabbis not to neglect treating me with kindness and favor. But I, O my master, do not desire this except from the Karaites who share my beliefs and faith...  Now, O my master, I have sought your favor and the favor of the kind people. Perhaps you will consider me as something and treat me with kindness and truth, as God has brought me among you. I have sought you out as I have sought others.  You, O my master, do in this matter as you see fit, according to your good deeds and excellent customs, for my masters and elders, the Karaites - may God strengthen them, prolong their lives, and save them from all trouble, enemy, ambush, and those who seek their harm. May He grant them favor, kindness, and mercy in His eyes and in the eyes of all who see them. Amen.  I ask God, who is not bound by need, not remembered by attributes, and not limited by regions, to save you from all trouble and distress... and not bring you to need the gifts of human hands, for man is born of woman, short of days and full of trouble. May He remove from you anger and trouble, and give you a future and hope, for you and all our Karaite brethren... May He increase and multiply you forever and ever. Amen.  [The letter ends with additional blessings and good wishes]

My letter to you, my daughter, from protected Jerusalem, on the 27th of the month of Rajab. I inform you, my daughter, of what is in my heart regarding your situation. My heart is on fire because of you. May God judge between you and those who have wronged you and made you an orphan while I am still alive. You, my daughter, should expect the grace of God. People [talk about] your mother's actions. I ask God Almighty not to forgive her sin, for because of her selfish desires, she has ruined you. May God claim your rights from her.  Know, my daughter, that I have taken an oath not to send you anything, and I am confused about your situation. I don't know what to do about your condition. God knows that there is nothing in my heart but grief and concern for you. However, in my body and all my circumstances, I am blessed. My clothes can barely contain me due to my joy and prosperity. If I wanted worldly success, I would be in a great position today, for I have become the agent for the Sultan's estates there, with ample provision and favor.  Your aunt has seen me, as well as her husband, and Abu al-Fadl is before me. I have authority to command and forbid, and I am a sultan. God has returned me to a better state than I was before. This is my prosperity, and the misfortune is for your mother, praise be to God.  Now, I don't know who you are with. I don't know if you are with the Jews, who are your father's people, or with your mother's people among the non-Jews. I inform you that if they were to sell you to me, I, your father, would buy you and rescue you from their hands. There is nothing else within my power.  I tell you that after Pentecost, I am leaving for the lands of Rum, to my country and my people. Let me know about yourself beforehand, and I will see what I can do about your situation, God willing.

human_translation: i am writing to you, my daughter, from jerusalem, may god keep it, on the 27th of rajab. i wish to tell you, my daughter, what i think about your affairs. fire is in my heart because of you; god is between me and that one who harmed and made you an orphan while i am alive. you, my daughter, must look for alms from strangers because of the deeds of your mother. i ask god, the exalted, not to forgive her that she destroyed you in order to satisfy her cupidity. he will punish her for what she has done to you. know, my daughter, that i have given a solemn oath not to send you anything as long as i am uncertain about your status and do not know how to act in regard with you. god knows that i have no worry or distress except you. otherwise, i am completely satisfied with my health and my affairs; my clothes do not hold me for happiness and good luck. had i sought only worldly gain, then i could regard myself today as a great success, for i have become the administrator of the estates of the sultan here in palestine, for an ample salary and fine income. your maternal aunt has seen me, and her husband too, and also abu l-fadl. the police are at my disposal, command and prohibition are in my hand, and i am a sultan. god has made me happier than i had been before; so the good fortune has been mine and the misfortune has come to your mother, and praise be to god. now, my daughter, i do not know with whom you are, with the jews, who are the stock of your father, or with the stock of your mother, the muslims. but this i wish you to know: even if they wanted to sell you to me, who are my own daughter, i would buy you and rescue you from their hands, except one other thing which i cannot do. after pentecost i am leaving for the lands of the rum byzantium to visit my native country and my family. let me know before what your intentions are so that i can decide what to do with you, if god will.

All of this is to be taken from the total of what is on the pledges that are recorded in the three Arabic documents detailing the pledges.  Those I have bequeathed to should take from the aforementioned pledged goods as I have described. What remains from the pledges should be added to my cash assets, which are 300 dinars present with me, and to 67 dinars also deposited with Lady Ikhtiyar, along with all that remains of my cash, goods, furnishings, and carpets. This should be kept for my son on the condition that I will mention: if he lives and reaches maturity, he will receive it. If, God forbid, he dies before that, then half of it goes to the synagogues in Egypt and to the poor in equal parts, and the other half is to be divided equally among my heirs, who are my brother, my sisters, and my cousins' children.  Nothing from this is to be given to his father, Hassun the Ashkeloni, except for two documents I have with him for 80 dinars. If my son reaches his predetermined end, it should be given to him along with 10 dinars from the total of what the boy leaves behind. ai_translation: This document certifies that the bearer, who was among the notables of Sunbat, whose house was open to all travelers and who never asked anything from anyone, is now in difficult times. He is being sought for two poll-tax payments, for himself and his son, as well as another debt.  Our master Matzliach HaCohen, Head of the Yeshiva of the Pride of Jacob, may he live forever, oversaw the repairs and management of a house in Qasr al-Sham' in Egypt, in the alley known as the Alley of the Poor. A quarter of this house belongs to the Hekdesh (religious endowment).  Maror Obadiah undertook necessary repairs to the house, spending a total of 24 dinars. The Hekdesh's share of this expense is 6 dinars. Maror Obadiah is entitled to recover this amount from the rent of the house, collecting it month by month after deducting costs for maintenance and guarding.  This document serves as proof for Maror Obadiah to collect the 6 1/4 dinars owed to him from the rent. Once he has recovered the full amount, the collection of rent will revert to its previous arrangement.  This was written in the middle ten days of the month of Tammuz, in the year 1445 of the era of documents, in Fustat, Egypt, which is on the Nile.  Signed by Nathan HaCohen son of Solomon HaCohen, and Halfon HaLevi son of Menashe.  Additional notes record partial payments received in various months.  The document concludes with instructions from the Great Court for the tenant to pay rent directly to the bearer until the debt is fully repaid.

ai_translation: Blessed are you who sow beside all waters, who send out freely the ox and the donkey. Blessed are those who maintain justice, who constantly do what is right. Blessed is he who has regard for the weak; the Lord delivers him in times of trouble. The Lord will protect him and preserve his life; he will bless him in the land and not surrender him to the desire of his foes.'  It has not been hidden from my master, the courts (may their Rock protect them), and the community (may they be blessed), the current situation and its difficulty for people of means, let alone the weak and the poor. I am a woman with weak eyesight; I cannot distinguish night from day, nor can I find my way when walking. My husband has fled to Alexandria, leaving me a living widow with a three-year-old child on my neck. We are hungry and naked, with nothing in our hands. If not for God Almighty and Sheikh Abu Ali (may his Rock protect him), who remembers us sometimes, we would have no means at all.  I have complained about my situation to God and to the community (may they be blessed), asking them to look into my situation before I die of hunger. Perhaps they will arrange something for me to cover myself with. May their reward be doubled from Heaven, and may their peace be eternal.  The wife of Ma'ani, who has fled.
